dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, have you seen this story about the Pentagon and Trump's Scottish resort? It's, like, quite a tangled web.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, uh, have you seen this story about the Pentagon and Trump's Scottish resort? It's, like, quite a tangled web.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, the one where they're talking about a record-breaking profit for Trump? Like, over $184,000, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, the one where they're talking about a record-breaking profit for Trump? Like, over one hundred eighty four thousand dollars, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Pentagon has spent at least $184,000if not moreat President Trumps Scottish resort since he took office, according to documents released by the House Oversight Committee on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it's all tied to 'military tourism.' But get this, B, it wasn't just, you know, soldiers choosing to go there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it's all tied to military tourism. But get this, B, it wasn't just, you know, soldiers choosing to go there.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, uh, because the documents from the House Oversight Committee suggest these were mandatory stays, weren't they? Like, 30 miles from their actual training grounds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, uh, because the documents from the House Oversight Committee suggest these were mandatory stays, weren't they? Like, thirty miles from their actual training grounds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Various crews have been put up 30 miles away, at Trump Turnberry, during overnight stopovers, Politico first reported.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Mandatory 'fun runs,' apparently. Under a new Pentagon initiative. I'm just picturing these guys.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mandatory fun runs, apparently. Under a new Pentagon initiative. I'm just picturing these guys.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The provided article does not mention 'fun runs' or a 'new Pentagon initiative' of this nature.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the Pentagon's angle is, like, this isn't them profiting from *their own* spending. They even praised Air Force flights to the area previously.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the Pentagon's angle is, like, this isn't them profiting from their own spending. They even praised Air Force flights to the area previously.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The article does not detail the Pentagon's specific 'angle' or mention them praising the flights, only that the House committee was investigating a 'surge in Air Force flights'.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] But they still spent, what, $125,000 on accommodation since 2017? And, like, another $60,000 on souvenirs?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they still spent, what, one hundred twenty five thousand dollars on accommodation since twenty seventeen? And, like, another sixty thousand dollars on souvenirs?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There was also about $60,000 spent at the resort that could not be tied to actual travel vouchers, with the Pentagons letter suggesting that it could have been used on meals and restaurants.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Mhm, $60,000 on souvenirs, all given back to the troops. And they're calling the accommodation a 'significant discount' at $189 a night, which apparently allowed for 660 rooms for these 'fun runs'.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mhm, sixty thousand dollars on souvenirs, all given back to the troops. And they're calling the accommodation a significant discount at one hundred eighty nine dollars a night, which apparently allowed for six hundred sixty rooms for these fun runs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At an average cost of $189 per night, that would suggest a total of 660 individual rooms paid for. There was also about $60,000 spent at the resort that could not be tied to actual travel vouchers, with the Pentagons letter suggesting that it could have been used on meals and restaurants.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A 'significant discount' at a Trump property, you know? It just... raises an eyebrow. This was all, uh, revealed in a memo to investigators looking into Trump's income.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A significant discount at a Trump property, you know? It just... raises an eyebrow. This was all, uh, revealed in a memo to investigators looking into Trump's income.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spending figure was disclosed in a letter sent to congressional investigators, who are probing whether Trump violated a constitutional provision prohibiting presidents from enriching themselves through the office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And then, here's the kicker: the Democratic House Oversight Committee leader actually voiced 'immense satisfaction' with the details!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And then, here's the kicker: the Democratic House Oversight Committee leader actually voiced immense satisfaction with the details!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While leaders of the Democratic House Oversight Committee voiced frustration with the limited details in the Pentagons response, it still reveals that far more taxpayer funds have been spent at the Presidents resort than previously known, they wrote back to the Pentagon on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I saw that! [overlaps] Like, 'efficiency of taxpayer funds.' It feels a bit sarcastic, no?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I saw that! Like, efficiency of taxpayer funds. It feels a bit sarcastic, no?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The provided article does not contain the quote 'efficiency of taxpayer funds'.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. I think the sarcasm level was off the charts there, um, considering they were exploring how Trump avoided constitutional provisions on presidential income.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. I think the sarcasm level was off the charts there, um, considering they were exploring how Trump avoided constitutional provisions on presidential income.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The spending figure was disclosed in a letter sent to congressional investigators, who are probing whether Trump violated a constitutional provision prohibiting presidents from enriching themselves through the office.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's not quite the 'record-breaking profit' narrative that initially grabbed headlines, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's not quite the record-breaking profit narrative that initially grabbed headlines, then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, and here's the other side of it, A. Since Trump took office, spending at his properties has, like, actually *decreased* across the board.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, and here's the other side of it, A. Since Trump took office, spending at his properties has, like, actually decreased across the board.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since he took office, spending at Trump properties by political candidates or organizations, including Trumps own campaign, has surged.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's right! The DC hotel, for instance, saw its profits slashed. I forgot about that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's right! The D C hotel, for instance, saw its profits slashed. I forgot about that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Trump hotel in Washington D.C., for instance, has become a hotspot for various lobbyists and political figures hoping to garner favor with the president.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and Forbes.com points out, uh, nearly a hundred members of Congress, hundreds of admin officials, even foreign officials, they all boycotted different Trump properties.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the Forbes dot com points out, uh, nearly a hundred members of Congress, hundreds of admin officials, even foreign officials, they all boycotted different Trump properties.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the last two years alone, at least 90 members of Congress, 250 administration officials and over 110 foreign officials from nearly 60 different countries have been seen at different Trump properties, according to a count by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, while this Scottish resort thing looks bad on the surface, the bigger picture is actually a lot more, uh, complicated than just 'Trump profiting hugely'.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, while this Scottish resort thing looks bad on the surface, the bigger picture is actually a lot more, uh, complicated than just Trump profiting hugely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. It's almost like, you know, perception versus the actual financial impact in other areas. A very mixed bag.
